Award.AwardTitle: MRI: Acquisition of an X-Ray Diffractometer to Enhance Research and Education at Southeastern New England Colleges
Award.AbstractNarration:
With this award from the Major Research Instrumentation Program (MRI) and support from the Chemistry Research Instrumentation Program (CRIF), Professor David Manke from the University of Massachussetts, Dartmouth and colleagues Maolin Guo, Steven Haefner (Bridgewater State University), Sivappa Rasapalli and Jonathan Rochford (U Mass Boston) will acquire a dual source X-ray diffractometer. In general, an X-ray diffractometer allows accurate and precise measurements of the full three-dimensional structure of a molecule, including bond distances and angles, and provides accurate information about the spatial arrangement of a molecule relative to neighboring molecules. The studies described here will impact a number of areas, including organic and inorganic chemistry, materials chemistry and biochemistry. This instrument will be an integral part of teaching as well as research and research training not only at the University of Massachusetts Dartmouth but also at neighboring institutions such as the University of Massachusetts Boston, Bridgewater State University, University of Rhode Island, Salve Regina University, Rhode Island College, and Brown University which are part of a consortium.


The award is aimed at enhancing research and education at all levels, especially in areas such as (a) designing and synthesizing Lewis base derivatized metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) to selectively remove carbon dioxide from gaseous mixtures; (b) studying capped, mixed bimetallic systems for the catalytic reduction of carbon dioxide; (c) developing mono- and bi-metallo-intercalators for site specific binding of DNA; (d) investigating molecular systems for application in photovoltaics, photocatalytic carbon dioxide reduction and photoacoustic imaging technologies; (e) studying bioinorganic chemistry of iron and hydrogen peroxide homeostasis; and (f) developing strategies for the preparation of complex organic molecules.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project allowed for the acquisition of an X-ray diffractometer and the creation of a facility for its shared use among the colleges and universities of Southeastern New England. The instrument has been used by groups from research universities, primarily undergraduate institutions, and community colleges. Cumulatively, the project has impacted nineteen groups at twelve academic institutions.

The diffractometer is one of the primary tools for determining the structure of small molecules and materials. The state-of-the-art instrument purchased through this grant was a dual source, shutterless instrument which has allowed the elucidation of inorganic and organic materials, in crystalline and powder form.

The instrument has greatly enhanced research efforts in both chemistry and engineering, including (1) the development of flow battery electrolytes, (2) the development of sensors for iron in live cells, (3) the synthesis of pharmaceutically relevant natural products, (4) the synthesis of an array of new coordination polymer based materials, (5) the development of new metal complexes with promise in catalysis, and (6) in water purification technology. Data obtained from this instrument has already been used in thirty nine peer-reviewed journal articles including authors at all levels - faculty (adjunct, assistant, associate, full and emeritus professors), graduate students (Ph.D. and Master's), undergraduate and community college students. The data has been used in many presentations, including ten at national meetings of the American Chemical Society, with talks on both the research and educational aspects of this project.

Beyond its research impact, the instrument has had outstanding educational impact. The diffractometer has resulted in the development of a new course in X-ray crystallography, and has been used in upper division laboratory courses. This instrument has also been the centerpiece of an outreach program between UMass Dartmouth and three area community colleges. This program provides in-semester research opportunities to community college students, and has already resulted in eight publications with community college student authors.

The project has accomplished its goals both by greatly enhancing the research capacity of many academic institutions, and by increasing the education and training of students in the region from community college to Ph.D. programs. The diffractometer will continue to be a critical component of the research and educational activities of the region for years to come.
